hobby.message: You still hunting political literature no one’s supposed to find?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I fold origami... from scrap forms mostly. It helps me think... quietly.
neutral_answer: Yeah. Hard to avoid them now.
Windows lit up all night.
I just stay in and fold paper cranes. Keeps my hands busy.
Scanners haven't left since the protests started.
You see more patrols than people lately.
Origami's kept me occupied indoors. Shame the blackout killed good lighting for detail work.
Still scanning, every corner. It's routine now.
Been folding more, keeps my mind off things.
Funny—couldn't find any decent paper after the lockdown last week.
Had to use receipts and ration slips for my origami. They don't crease right, but it works.
Helps pass the hours when you can't really sleep.
Still constant scans out there. Always on edge now.
The city’s so tense, even hobby shops shuttered.
I’ve been folding origami at home—complex stuff, like modular tessellations.
The blackout ruined half my models. Had to start from scratch by candlelight.
Funny, how folding scraps feels like fighting the system. Something precise, when nothing else is.
Guess I make more than I used to, especially after the disappearances.
They're scanning, and the drones are closer than ever lately.
Can’t even get proper folding paper since my BCI dropped.
I picked up origami when I started spotting BCI errors—needed something I could control.
I fold animals from security notices, protest fliers—anything thin enough to crease.
After the leak, neighbors left me paper by the door. We fold together in silence now.
Used to be just decoration. Now the cranes are for vigils, and for the missing.
Sometimes it feels like the only way to speak safely—leaving folded messages in plain sight.
Strange what becomes subversive, huh? Just paper, once.
hobby_answer: Yeah. Still helps, sometimes.
Keeps my mind focused.
Paper's getting harder to find lately, with deliveries delayed.
I just keep folding, even during blackouts.
Hard not to notice the protests outside.
It does, most days.
Folding calms things down, lets me tune out the alarms.
Had trouble getting good paper after last week—whole block's on edge now.
Hard to ignore what’s happening in the streets.
People keep knocking for cranes but don’t say why.
Lately, it feels like everyone’s folding for someone lost.
It’s reliable. More than the system, anyway.
Folding is muscle memory. Five cranes in the time it takes to log in.
Last night, I folded through another curfew—sirens, shouts outside, couldn’t stop.
Usually, I fold alone. Now neighbors are sliding paper notes under my door.
First time I’ve seen people use origami at vigils—easier than words.
Hard to make clean creases when your BCI tanks and your hands are shaking.
Guess it connects me to what’s left of normal.
Yeah, it works better than most things on bad nights.
Origami keeps my head clear. There’s something about the repetition.
I used to fold just birds, but now every model feels urgent—something to mark time.
During the latest blackout, neighbors knocked to trade paper—it felt strange, kind of necessary.
People are folding for the missing. I never thought paper cranes would mean protest.
Losing access to supplies has forced improvising—scraps, old memos, ration papers.
There’s comfort in folding with someone beside the blackout glass.
The city’s grief somehow lives in these birds now.
Always. Folding’s been my fallback since before all this chaos.
When I can’t sleep, I build kusudamas from scrap—sometimes from forms left by vanished colleagues.
After the leak, paper got scarce. I started sharing what I had with the neighbor, passing notes.
We both joined a vigil from our apartments—every paper model became a message for the lost.
Machine failures and lockdowns used to mean quiet; now, they drive knock signals between floors.
I left a whole string of cranes at the service window, and someone added more overnight.
Hard to admit, but I see fear in people’s folding now—their hands tremble like mine.
The city’s unrest seeps into the folds. Sometimes, it helps me feel less alone.
Origami used to be private. Now, it’s a quiet rebellion across every lit window.
